options.t: 1. In adults with sinus disease, we recommend against XR. (↓↓)
2. In adults with uncomplicated acute sinusitis (≤4 weeks), we recommend against imaging. (↓↓)
3. In adults with acute sinusitis with suspected complications, we recommend CT as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 3.1 In adults where there is clinical or radiologic concern for intraorbital or intracranial complication, we suggest MRI as the next imaging modality.

options.v: Chronic or Recurrent Acute Sinusitis: CT
options.t: 4. In adults who meet the definition (e.g., Canadian Consensus Guidelines) of chronic sinusitis OR for recurrent acute sinusitis, we suggest CT as the initial imaging modality (↑).
1. In adults with suspected sinonasal tumour, we recommend CT as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 In adults with suspected sinonasal tumour on CT, we recommend MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
1. In adults with pulsatile tinnitus, we suggest CT/CTA or MRI/MRA as the initial imaging modality.
1. In adults with symmetrical atraumatic non-pulsatile tinnitus with no associated neurological signs and symptoms, we recommend against imaging. (↓↓)
2. In adults with associated neurological signs and symptoms꙳ OR with asymmetric atraumatic non-pulsatile tinnitus, we recommend MRI of internal auditory canals as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Internal Auditory Canal Assessment: MRI unavailable/contraindicated
options.t: ↪ 2.1 If MRI internal auditory canals is unavailable or contraindicated, we recommend CT. (↑↑)
Palpable nodule, including goiter
1. In adults with palpable thyroid nodule or goiter, we recommend US as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Thyroid nodule/goiter with suspicion for invasive thyroid cancer: next imaging
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required to evaluate for indications such as suspicion of invasive thyroid cancer, substernal and deep extension, tracheal compression, we recommend CT as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
1. In adults with biochemical confirmation of thyrotoxicosis or hyperthyroidism (i.e., supressed TSH), we recommend US as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If focal abnormality is detected on US, we suggest NM. (↑)
1. In adults with biochemically proven primary hyperparathyroidism, we recommend US and NM as the initial imaging modalities for operative consideration. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If US and NM are nondiagnostic or discordant, we suggest CT as the next imaging modality at the physicians’ discretion. (↑)

options.v: Neck mass of unknown origin, including salivary gland mass

options.t: 1. In adults with neck mass of unknown origin with clinical concern for malignancy, we recommend CT as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
2. In adults with neck mass of unknown origin with low clinical concern for malignancy, we recommend US as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 2.1 If further investigation is required to characterize the mass, we recommend CT or MRI as the next imaging modality based on US findings. (↑↑)
1. In adults with suspected acute sialadenitis with or without stone, we recommend CT as the initial imaging modality. (EPc)
↪ 1.1 If CT is unavailable, we recommend US as the initial imaging modality. (EPc)
1. In adults with xerostomia, suspected chronic sialadenitis, or suspected autoimmune/connective tissue disease, we recommend US or CT as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑ or EPc)
↪ 1.1  If further investigation is required, we suggest MRI/MR sialography as the next imaging modality. (↑)
1. In adults with temporomandibular joint dysfunction, we suggest against imaging, unless surgery is being considered. (↓)

options.v: TMJ dysfunction/TMD after conservative management failure
options.t: ↪ 1.1 In adults with clinically significant mechanical symptoms suggestive of temporomandibular joint dysfunction where surgery is being considered after failure of conservative management, we recommend MRI. (↑↑)
Osteomyelitis, including diabetic foot

options.v: Suspected Osteomyelitis / diabetic foot: initial imaging
options.t: 1. In adults with suspected osteomyelitis, including the diabetic foot, we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required, we recommend MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

↪ 1.2 If MRI is unavailable or contraindicated, we suggest CT (with contrast) or NM (bone scan). For bone scan, the radioisotope and protocol employed may vary based on clinical presentation, regional practice preferences and resource availability. (↑)
2. In adults with suspected osteomyelitis, we recommend CT for evaluation of sequestra or for guiding biopsy. (↑↑)
3. In adults with suspected osteomyelitis, where MRI or CT were not performed, we suggest US to evaluate for superficial fluid collections. (↑)
1. In adults with suspected septic arthritis, we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required, we recommend MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.2 If MRI is unavailable or contraindicated, we suggest CT (with contrast). (↑)

options.v: Septic arthritis﹘joint effusion and juxta-articular fluid collections: evaluation
options.t: 2. In adults with suspected septic arthritis, where MRI or CT were not performed, we suggest US to evaluate for effusion or juxta-articular fluid collections. (↑)
3. In adults with suspected septic arthritis, we suggest US or Fluoroscopy to facilitate arthrocentesis, immediately after XR, if bedside arthrocentesis is not feasible. (EPc)
1. In adults with suspected soft tissue infection, including necrotizing fasciitis, we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Deep Soft Tissue Infection: next imaging
options.t: 2. In adults with suspected deep or aggressive soft tissue infection, we recommend MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Deep Soft Tissue Infection: alternative imaging
options.t: ↪ 2.1 If MRI is unavailable or contraindicated, we suggest CT (with contrast). (↑)
3. In adults with suspected soft tissue infection, we suggest US to evaluate for superficial fluid collections. (↑)
↪ 3.1 If further investigation is required, we recommend MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 3.2 If MRI is unavailable or contraindicated, we suggest CT (with contrast). (↑)
Bone tumour — Primary

options.v: Suspected Primary Bone Tumour: initial imaging
options.t: 1. In adults with suspected primary bone tumour, we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required, we recommend MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.2 If MRI is unavailable or contraindicated, we suggest CT (with contrast). (↑)
↪ 1.3 If XR, MRI or CT remain equivocal, we suggest NM (bone scan). (EPc)
Bone tumour — Metastases
1. In adults with known primary cancer (non-myeloma), we recommend NM (bone scan) as the initial imaging modality to assess for skeletal metastases. (↑↑)
2. In adults with suspected bone metastases, we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality for assessment of focal symptomatic sites, or for correlation with a NM, MRI or CT finding. (↑↑)
3. In adults with metastases seen on XR requiring further local assessment or staging, we recommend MRI. (↑↑)
↪ 3.1 If MRI is unavailable or contraindicated, we suggest CT (with contrast). (↑)
4. In adults with suspected metastases, we recommend against skeletal survey XR. (↓↓)
5. In adults with suspected bone metastases, whole-body CT, whole-body MRI, and PET are evolving techniques and may be used depending on regional practice preferences and resource availability. (EPc)
Bone tumour — Myeloma
1. In adults with suspected myeloma, we recommend whole-body CT (low dose) or PET/CT as the initial imaging modality for staging. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If whole-body CT or PET/CT is negative or unavailable, we recommend whole-body MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.2 If whole-body CT, PET/CT, and MRI are unavailable or contraindicated, we suggest XR (skeletal survey). (↑)
2. In adults with known myeloma, we recommend XR for assessment of focal symptomatic sites, or for correlation with an MRI or CT finding. (↑↑)
3. In adults with suspected myeloma, we recommend against NM (bone scan). (↓↓)

options.v: Superficial Soft Tissue Mass or Tumour: initial imaging
options.t: 1. In adults with superficial soft tissue mass, we recommend US as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Superficial Mass or Tumour: next imaging
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required, we recommend MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Deep Soft Tissue Mass or Tumour: initial imaging
options.t: 2. In adults with deep or large soft tissue mass (≥5 cm), we recommend MRI as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Deep Soft Tissue Mass or Tumour: alternative imaging
options.t: ↪ 2.1 If MRI is unavailable or contraindicated, we suggest CT (with contrast). (↑)

options.v: Superficial Soft Tissue Mass or Tumour: Bone Involvement Assessment
options.t: 3. In adults with soft tissue masses, we recommend XR for evaluation of calcification, or if bone/joint involvement is suspected, after US. (↑↑)
Soft tissue pain (non-periarticular)
1. In adults with non-joint soft tissue pain, we recommend US as the initial imaging modality. (EPc)
↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required, we recommend MRI as the next imaging modality. (EPc)
↪ 1.2 If MRI is unavailable or contraindicated, we suggest CT (with contrast). (EPc)
2. In adults with non-joint soft tissue pain, we suggest XR for evaluation of regional bone pathology. (EPc)
Osteoarthritis/ Crystalline Arthropathy
1. In adults with suspected osteoarthritis or crystalline arthropathy, we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
2. In adults with suspected gout, we suggest US as a complement to XR to identify tophi. (↑)
3. In adults with suspected gout, CT (dual-energy) may be used depending on regional practice preferences and resource availability. (EPc)
Inflammatory Arthropathy (Rheumatoid/ Peripheral Spondyloarthropathy)
1. In adults with suspected inflammatory arthropathy, we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required for evaluation of findings such as effusion, synovitis, erosions and enthesitis, we suggest US as the next imaging modality. (↑)
↪ 1.2 In adults with multifocal joint pain, we suggest NM (bone scan) as an alternative to US to determine the distribution of synovitis. (↑)

↪ 1.3 If further investigation is required for evaluation of findings such as acute synovitis, cartilage damage, erosions, and bone marrow edema OR as an alternative to US, we suggest MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑)
Spondyloarthropathy (Axial)
1. In adults with suspected axial spondyloarthropathy, we recommend XR of the sacroiliac joints ± spine as the initial imaging investigation. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required, we recommend MRI of the sacroiliac joints ± spine as the next imaging investigation. (↑↑)
↪ 1.2 If MRI is unavailable or contraindicated, we suggest CT of the sacroiliac joints ± spine. (↑)
2. In adults with suspected axial spondyloarthropathy, we recommend against NM (bone scan). (↓↓)
Bone pain (non-joint)
1. In adults with non-traumatic, non-joint bone pain, we recommend XR of the symptomatic area(s) as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required, we recommend MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.2 If MRI is unavailable or contraindicated, we suggest CT. (EPc)
↪ 1.3 If CT is unavailable, we recommend NM (bone scan). (↑↑)
Metabolic bone disease, including osteoporosis and osteomalacia
1. In adults with suspected osteoporosis, we recommend Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) for the measurement of bone mineral density. (↑↑)
2. In adults with suspected metabolic bone disease with pain or focal area of concern, we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 2.1 If further investigation is required, we recommend MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 2.2 If MRI is not available or is contraindicated, we suggest CT to evaluate focal pain. (↑)
3. In adults with suspected metabolic bone disease with multi-focal areas of pain or concern, we suggest NM (bone scan) as the initial imaging modality. (↑)
Stress fracture (insufficiency, fatigue)
1. In adults with suspected stress (fatigue or insufficiency) fracture, we recommend XR of the area of interest as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required for evaluation of suspected stress fracture, we recommend MRI for the pelvis and hip and suggest MRI for any other sites as the next imaging modality. (↑↑/EPc)
↪ 1.2 If MRI is unavailable or is contraindicated or would result in a clinically significant delay in diagnosis, we suggest CT. (↑)
↪ 1.3 If CT is unavailable, we suggest NM (bone scan). (↑)
1. In adults with non-traumatic chest wall pain, we recommend XR of the chest ± ribs as the initial imaging investigation. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required for evaluation of focal chest wall or joint area of concern, we suggest US as the next imaging modality. (↑)
↪ 1.2 If further investigation is required, we recommend MRI. (↑↑)

options.v: Diffuse Chest Wall Pathology: follow-up imaging
options.t: ↪ 1.3 If further investigation is required for evaluation of diffuse chest wall or intra-thoracic pathology, we recommend CT as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
1. In adults with shoulder pain or instability, we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Shoulder Assessment: follow-up imaging / Rotator Cuff Assessment
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required for evaluation of soft tissue pathology, such as rotator cuff tear, tendinopathy, effusion, bursitis, soft tissue calcification, or extra-articular impingement, we recommend US as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.2 If further investigation is required OR as an alternative to US, we recommend MRI. (↑↑)
1. In adults with elbow joint pain of suspected articular origin, we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required, we recommend MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Elbow tendon / nerve compression / effusion / synovitis / bursitis: initial imaging
options.t: 2. In adults with elbow pain with suspected tendon pathology, nerve compression, effusion, synovitis, or bursitis, we recommend XR or US as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Elbow tendon / nerve compression / effusion / synovitis / bursitis: follow-up imaging
options.t: ↪ 2.1 If further investigation is required, we recommend MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
3. In adults with elbow pain, after XR, we suggest CT for evaluation of clinically relevant bone anatomy, in the context of pre-operative planning. (↑)
1. In adults with hand and/or wrist joint pain, we suggest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑)
↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required, we suggest MRI. (↑)

options.v: Hand/wrist ligament and capsule evaluation, MRI unavailable
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If MRI is unavailable or contraindicated, we suggest CT arthrography for the evaluation of the triangulofibrocartilaginous complex (TFCC), intrinsic ligaments of the wrist or capsule. (↑)

options.v: Hand/wrist soft tissue pathology / ganglion cyst / synovitis / tenosynovitis: initial imaging
options.t: 2. In adults with hand and/or wrist pain suspected to be soft tissue related, such as ganglion cyst, synovitis, tenosynovitis, we suggest US as the initial imaging modality. (↑)
↪ 2.1 As an alternative to US, we suggest MRI. (↑)

options.v: Hand/wrist pain, Follow-up Imaging for chronic scaphoid fracture or pre-operative evaluation
options.t: 3. In adults with hand and/or wrist pain, after XR, we suggest CT for evaluation of bone anatomy, chronic scaphoid fracture OR in the context of pre-operative planning. (↑)
1. In adults with hip pain, we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Hip internal derangement evaluation (labral tear, osteochondral injury, intraarticular body)
options.t: 2. For evaluation of internal derangement of the hip such as labral tear, osteochondral injury, or intraarticular body and if further investigation is required, we recommend MR arthrography or high-field MRI (i.e., 3T). (↑↑/EPc)
↪ 2.1 If MRI is unavailable or is contraindicated, we suggest CT arthrography for evaluation for internal derangement of the hip. (↑)
3. For evaluation of deep soft tissue pathology, after XR, we recommend MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Superficial soft tissue pathology: follow-up imaging
options.t: 4. For evaluation of superficial soft tissue pathology, after XR, we recommend US or MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
5. In adults with hip pain, we suggest CT for evaluation of clinically relevant bone anatomy, typically in the context of pre-operative planning. (EPc)
6. In adults with musculoskeletal pelvic pain, we suggest XR as the initial imaging modality. (EPc)
↪ 6.1 If further investigation is required, we suggest MRI as the next imaging modality. (EPc)
↪ 6.2 If MRI is unavailable or contraindicated, we suggest US if pathology is favoured to be soft tissue related. (EPc)
↪ 6.3 If MRI is unavailable or contraindicated, we suggest CT or NM (bone scan) if pathology is favoured to be osseous. (EPc)
1. In adults with knee joint pain, we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required, we recommend MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Knee joint pain: follow-up imaging, MRI unavailable (meniscal tear, chondral defects)
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If MRI is unavailable or contraindicated, we suggest CT arthrography to evaluate for findings such as meniscal tear or chondral defects. (↑)

options.v: Knee pain, soft tissue: initial imaging
options.t: 2. In adults with knee pain suspected to be soft tissue related, such as extensor mechanism pathology, bursitis, joint effusion, and popliteal cyst/mass, we recommend US as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Knee pain (extensor mechanism pathology, bursitis, joint effusion, popliteal cyst/mass): initial imaging
Knee pain, soft tissue - Alternative imaging
options.t: ↪ 2.1 As an alternative to US, we recommend MRI. (↑↑)

options.v: Chronic knee joint pain, bone anatomy - Pre-operative evaluation
options.t: 3. In adults with chronic knee joint pain, after XR, we suggest CT for evaluation of clinically relevant bone anatomy in scenarios such as patellofemoral maltracking, osteochondral defect, or intraarticular bodies OR in the context of pre-operative planning. (↑ OR EPc)
1. In adults with ankle pain, we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Ankle pain: follow-up imaging (effusion, tendon abnormality)
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required for evaluation of effusion or tendon abnormality, we recommend US as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Ankle pain: Further Imaging (ligament and osteochondral evaluation)
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If further investigation is required to evaluate for findings such as osteochondral lesion or unstable ligament tears, or as an alternative to US for tendon pathology, we recommend MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Ankle pain: osteochondral efect, intraarticular bodies, tarsal coalition / pre-operative evaluation
options.t: 2. In adults with ankle pain, after XR, we suggest CT for evaluation of clinically significant bone anatomy in scenarios such as osteochondral defect, intraarticular bodies, tarsal coalition OR in the context of pre-operative planning. (↑ OR EPc)
1. In adults with foot pain, we suggest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: Foot pain, soft tissue related: initial imaging
options.t: 2. In adults with foot pain suspected to be soft tissue related, such as plantar fasciitis, tendon pathology, bursitis, Morton’s neuroma, we suggest US as the next imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: Foot pain: stress fracture, osteochondral defect, tarsal coalition, plantar fasciitis, tarsal tunnel syndrome, tnedon pathology, or Morton's neuroma
options.t: ↪ 2.1 If further investigation is required for evaluation for findings such as stress fracture, tarsal coalition, plantar fasciitis, tarsal tunnel syndrome, tendon pathology, or Morton’s neuroma, we suggest MRI. (↑)

options.v: Foot pain: stress fracture, osteochondral defect or pre-operative evaluation
options.t: 3. In adults with foot pain, after XR, we suggest CT for evaluation of pathologies such as stress fracture, osteochondral defect OR for evaluation of clinically relevant bone anatomy, typically in the context of pre-operative planning. (↑↑ OR EPc)

options.v: Foot pain: suspected stress fracture, alternative assessment
options.t: 4. In adults with foot pain suspected to be a stress fracture, if MRI and CT are unavailable or contraindicated, we suggest NM (bone scan). (↑)

1. In adults with orthopedic hardware/arthroplasty pain or symptoms, we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality, to evaluate for findings such as fracture, dislocation, periprosthetic osteolysis, or hardware fracture/loosening. (↑↑)

↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required for evaluation of periprosthetic osteolysis or fracture, we recommend CT as the next imaging modality. Metal artifact reduction parameters should be implemented. (↑↑)

↪ 1.2 In adults with orthopedic hardware/arthroplasty pain or symptoms suspicious for infection, loosening, or fracture, we recommend NM (bone scan) when CT is negative, indeterminate, or unavailable. (↑↑)

options.v: Orthopedic hardware/arthroplasty pain, soft tissue evaluation: follow-up imaging
options.t: 2. In adults with orthopedic hardware/arthroplasty pain or symptoms suspected to be related to soft tissue pathology, after XR, we recommend MRI as the next imaging modality. Metal artifact reduction sequences should be implemented. (↑↑)

options.v: Orthopedic hardware/arthroplasty pain, soft tissue evaluation: alternative imaging
options.t: ↪ 2.1 If MRI is not available or contraindicated, we suggest CT (with contrast). (↑)

options.v: Orthopedic hardware/arthroplasty pain, superficial fluid collections
options.t: 3. In adults with orthopedic hardware/arthroplasty pain or symptoms, we recommend US to evaluate for superficial fluid collections. (↑↑)

options.v: Orthopedic hardware/arthroplasty pain, septic arthritis evaluation
options.t: 4. In adults with orthopedic hardware/arthroplasty pain or symptoms concerning for septic arthritis, after XR, we suggest US or Fluoroscopy to facilitate arthrocentesis. (EPc)
1. In adults with suspected avascular necrosis/bone infarction, we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required for evaluation of avascular necrosis, we recommend MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.2 If MRI is unavailable or is contraindicated, we suggest NM (bone scan). (↑)
↪ 1.3 If MRI and NM (bone scan) are unavailable or contraindicated, we suggest CT. (↑)
Complex regional pain syndrome

options.v: Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS): initial imaging
options.t: 1. In adults with suspected complex regional pain syndrome, we suggest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS): next imaging
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required, we suggest NM (bone scan) as the next imaging modality. (EPc)

options.v: Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS): alternative imaging
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If NM is unavailable or is contraindicated, we suggest MRI. (EPc)

options.v: Acute coronary syndrome: ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)

options.t: 1. In patients meeting criteria for STEMI (i.e., ECG), we recommend invasive coronary angiography as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

↪ 1.1 In cases of diagnostic uncertainty OR if immediate invasive coronary angiography is unavailable, we suggest chest XR and bedside TTE/POCUS (if available) to evaluate for other potential causes of chest pain, but this should not delay care. (↑)

1. In patients with suspected non-STEMI, we recommend chest XR (to rule out other causes of chest pain) and bedside TTE/POCUS (if available, to evaluate for ventricular function and rule out pericardial effusion) as the initial imaging modalities. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 In higher-risk patients, we recommend invasive coronary angiography as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.2 In lower-risk patients, we recommend invasive coronary angiography or CCTA as the next imaging modality, depending on clinical parameters. (↑↑)

1. In patients with suspected unstable angina (i.e., negative cardiac troponin), we recommend chest XR (to rule out other causes of chest pain) and bedside TTE/POCUS (if available, to evaluate for ventricular function and rule out pericardial effusion) as the initial imaging modalities. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 For assessment of coronary artery disease and for risk stratification, we recommend CCTA. (↑↑)
2. In patients with suspected unstable angina with ongoing chest pain not relieved with medical management, we recommend invasive coronary angiography. (↑↑)
1. For patients with suspected acute aortic syndrome, we recommend CTA (preferably cardiac-gated, if available) as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If CTA is contraindicated, we recommend TEE or MRA as alternative imaging modalities. (↑↑)

1. In patients with suspected pulmonary embolism with low or intermediate pretest probability (as determined by a structured risk assessment tool) with a negative D-dimer, we recommend against CTA/MRA/VQ scan. (↓↓)

2. In patients with suspected pulmonary embolism with low or intermediate pretest probability (as determined by a structured risk assessment tool) with a positive D-dimer test, we recommend CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA) as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 2.1 If immediate CTPA is not available, we recommend chest XR as the next imaging modality to exclude other causes of chest pain. (↑↑)
↪ 2.2 If CT pulmonary angiography is contraindicated, we suggest VQ scan or MR pulmonary angiography as an alternative. (↑)

3. In patients with suspected pulmonary embolism and high pretest probability (as determined by a structured risk assessment tool) or in patients with recurrent pulmonary embolism, we recommend CTPA as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 3.1 If immediate CTPA is not available, we recommend chest XR as the next imaging modality to exclude other causes of chest pain. (↑↑)

options.v: High risk PE contraindicated CT alternatives
options.t: ↪ 3.2 If CT pulmonary angiography is contraindicated, we suggest VQ scan or MR pulmonary angiography as an alternative. (↑)

options.v: Pregnancy high risk PE initial assessment
options.t: 4. For pregnant patients with high pretest probability (as determined by a structured risk assessment tool) of pulmonary embolism, we recommend chest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 4.1 If chest XR does not explain the clinical presentation and further imaging is required, we recommend Doppler US as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 4.2 If Doppler US is negative, we recommend CTPA or NM (VQ scan) as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
5. In patients with pulmonary hypertension suspected to be secondary to chronic thromboembolic disease (CTEPH), we recommend VQ scan as the initial imaging modality. (EPc)

↪ 5.1 If VQ scan is non-diagnostic, indeterminate for chronic pulmonary embolism, or unavailable, we recommend CTPA as an alternative. Dual energy CT technology or iodine subtraction maps can increase CTPA sensitivity to detect chronic pulmonary embolism. (EPc)
1. In patients with suspected acute myocarditis, we recommend TTE followed by cardiac MRI as the initial imaging modalities. (↑↑)

↪ 1.1 If cardiac MRI does not demonstrate acute myocarditis and if invasive coronary angiography has not been performed, we suggest CCTA as the next imaging modality to exclude obstructive coronary artery disease in appropriately selected patients. (↑)

1. In patients with suspected acute pericarditis, we recommend bedside TTE/POCUS or TEE as the initial imaging modality to assess presence of pericardial thickening, effusion, as well as ventricular function and constrictive physiology. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If further imaging is required to guide management (i.e., pericardiocentesis), we suggest CT (preferably cardiac-gated, if available) as the next imaging modality. (↑)
↪ 1.2 If TTE is inconclusive regarding acute pericarditis or constrictive physiology, we suggest cardiac MRI as an alternative. (↑)

1. In patients with established chronic ischemic heart disease with recurrent chest pain symptoms despite guideline directed medical therapy and intermediate risk/pre-test probability or known non-obstructive CAD, we suggest anatomical (CCTA), functional (stress NM, stress echo) imaging, or stress MR as the initial imaging modalities. (↑)
↪ 1.1 To identify patients who may benefit from further investigation with invasive coronary angiography, we suggest CT-fractional flow reserve (CT-FFR). (↑)

2. In patients with established chronic ischemic heart disease with recurrent chest pain symptoms despite guideline directed medical therapy and high risk/pre-test probability, we recommend invasive coronary angiography as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

3. In patients with established chronic ischemic heart disease with prior coronary revascularization with percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) or coronary artery bypass grafts (CABG) and with recurrent chest pain symptoms, we suggest CCTA to evaluate for stent (especially if stent > 3mm) or graft patency. (↑)
↪ 3.1 If evaluation for ischemia to account for symptoms is important, we recommend NM (myocardial perfusion scan). (↑↑)

4. In patients with stable chest pain without established ischemic heart disease presenting to the outpatient clinic and at low risk/pre-test likelihood of having obstructive CAD (as determined by a structured assessment tool), routine imaging investigations are not recommended. (↓↓)
↪ 4.1 In selected patient populations, we suggest calcium score CT (for excluding calcified plaque and identifying patients at low likelihood of obstructive CAD) or exercise ECG testing. (↑)

5. In patients without established chronic ischemic heart disease with recurrent stable chest pain symptoms and intermediate or high risk/pre-test probability, we recommend CCTA for diagnosis of CAD, risk prognostication and guiding of treatment decisions. (↑↑)

↪ 5.1 For diagnosis of myocardial ischemia and estimation of risk of major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE), we recommend functional imaging (stress echocardiography or PET/SPECT MPI or CMR). (↑↑)

options.v: Cardiovascular screening and risk stratification (calcium score CT)

options.t: 1. In asymptomatic low-risk adults, we suggest against routine cardiovascular imaging screening and risk stratification. (↓)

2. In asymptomatic intermediate-risk adults, we recommend calcium score CT for optimal risk stratification to guide medical management. In high-risk patients reluctant to initiate optimal medical management, calcium score CT can provide useful information for patient counselling. (↑↑)
1. In patients with suspected pericardial effusion, we recommend TTE as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

↪ 1.1 If there is suspected effusive constrictive/constrictive physiology, we suggest CT (preferably cardiac-gated, if available) as the next imaging modality to evaluate for pericardial thickness, pericardial effusion, and calcification. (↑)
↪ 1.2 If TTE is inconclusive for effusive constrictive/constrictive physiology, we recommend cardiac MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.3 If cardiac MRI is inconclusive for effusive constrictive/constrictive physiology, we recommend cardiac catheterization. (↑↑)
1. In patients with suspected constrictive pericarditis, we recommend TTE as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If there is suspected constrictive physiology, we suggest CT (preferably cardiac-gated, if available) as the next imaging modality to evaluate for pericardial thickness and calcification. (↑)
↪ 1.2 If TTE is inconclusive for constrictive physiology, we recommend cardiac MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.3 If cardiac MRI is inconclusive for constrictive physiology, we recommend cardiac catheterization. (↑↑)
1. In patients with a suspected intracardiac or pericardial mass (versus normal variant) detected on chest CT, we recommend TTE as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If further imaging is required, we recommend cardiac MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.2 If cardiac MRI is not tolerated, is unavailable, or is contraindicated, we recommend cardiac CT as an alternative imaging modality. (↑↑)
2. In patients with a suspected intracardiac or pericardial mass (versus normal variant) incidentally detected on TTE, we recommend cardiac MRI for further characterization. (↑↑)
↪ 2.1 If cardiac MRI is not tolerated, is unavailable, or is contraindicated, we recommend cardiac CT as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
1. In patients with intracardiac or pericardial mass detected on chest CT, we recommend TTE as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If further imaging is required, we recommend cardiac MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.2 If cardiac MRI is not tolerated, is unavailable, or is contraindicated, we recommend cardiac CT as an alternative imaging modality. (↑↑)
2. In patients with intracardiac or pericardial mass detected on TTE, we recommend cardiac MRI for further characterization. (↑↑)
↪ 2.1 If cardiac MRI is not tolerated, is unavailable, or is contraindicated, we recommend cardiac CT as the next imaging modality. Cardiac PET may be helpful to guide management. (↑↑)
1. In patients with suspected aortic valve stenosis, we recommend TTE as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

↪ 1.1 If the severity of the aortic valve stenosis is unclear (for example in suspected low flow low gradient severe aortic valve stenosis), we recommend calcium score CT of the aortic valve as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.2 In patients with suspected aortic valve stenosis where pulmonary edema is suspected, we recommend chest XR as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
2. In patients with suspected aortic valve regurgitation, we recommend TTE as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

↪ 2.1 If further imaging is required due to poor acoustic windows or if information about ventricular size and function is required, we recommend cardiac MRI as the next imaging modality or TEE if the mechanism or severity of aortic valve regurgitation is unclear. (↑↑)
↪ 2.2 If MRI is not tolerated, is unavailable, or is contraindicated, we recommend cardiac CT as an alternative imaging modality for evaluation of ventricular size and function. (↑↑)

options.v: Aortic valve regurgitation - Suspected pulmonary edema
options.t: ↪ 2.3 In patients with suspected aortic valve regurgitation where pulmonary edema is suspected, we recommend chest XR as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

3. After completing TTE for aortic valve disease, we recommend TEE for suspected infective endocarditis, to further characterize stenosis severity or mechanism of regurgitation, and for ruling out aortic root abscess. (↑↑)

options.v: Aortic valve disease - Suspected aortic root abscess
options.t: ↪ 3.1 If there is concern for aortic root abscess and TEE is contraindicated, we recommend cardiac CT. (↑↑)

4. In patients with prosthetic valve, we recommend TTE and TEE for suspected infective endocarditis, to further characterize stenosis severity or mechanism of regurgitation, and for ruling out aortic root abscess. (↑↑)

options.v: Prosthetic valve - Suspected aortic root abscess
options.t: ↪ 4.1 If there is concern for aortic root abscess and TEE is contraindicated, we recommend cardiac CT. (↑↑)
1. In patients with suspected mitral valve stenosis, we recommend TTE as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If intervention is contemplated or required, we recommend TEE as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Mitral valve stenosis - Suspected pulmonary edema
options.t: 2. In patients with suspected mitral valve stenosis where pulmonary edema is suspected, we recommend chest XR as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
3. In patients with suspected mitral valve regurgitation, we recommend TTE as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Mitral valve regurgitation - Mechanism or severity unclear
options.t: ↪ 3.1 If the mechanism or severity is unclear on TTE, we recommend TEE as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

↪ 3.2 If further imaging is required due to poor acoustic windows OR if information about ventricular size and function or confirmation of mitral regurgitation severity is required, we recommend cardiac MRI as the next imaging modality (↑↑). (↑↑)

options.v: Mitral valve regurgitation - Suspected pulmonary edema
options.t: 4. In patients with suspected mitral valve regurgitation where pulmonary edema is suspected, we recommend chest XR as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
1. In patients with suspected pulmonary valve disease, we recommend TTE as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected pulmonary valve disease - Further imaging
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If further imaging is required due to poor acoustic windows or if information about ventricular size and function is required (e.g., tetralogy of Fallot), we recommend cardiac MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected pulmonary valve disease - Alternative imaging
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If cardiac MRI is not tolerated, is unavailable, or is contraindicated, we recommend cardiac CT as an alternative imaging modality. (↑↑)

2. After completing TTE for pulmonary valve disease, we suggest TEE for suspected infective endocarditis, to further characterize stenosis severity or mechanism of regurgitation, and for ruling out abscess. (↑)

options.v: Suspected pulmonary valve disease - Complex pathology
options.t: 3. In patients with suspected pulmonary valve disease where supra and sub-valvular pathologies are possible based on TTE findings, we recommend cardiac MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected pulmonary valve disease - Alternative imaging
options.t: ↪ 3.1 If cardiac MRI is not tolerated, is unavailable, or is contraindicated, we recommend cardiac CT as an alternative imaging modality. (↑↑)
1. In patients with suspected tricuspid valve disease, we recommend TTE as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected tricuspid valve disease - Further imaging
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If further imaging is required due to poor acoustic windows or if information about ventricular size and function is required, we recommend cardiac MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected tricuspid valve disease - Alternative imaging
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If cardiac MRI is not tolerated, is unavailable, or is contraindicated, we recommend cardiac CT as an alternative imaging modality. (↑↑)

2. After completing TTE for tricuspid valve disease, we suggest TEE for suspected infective endocarditis, to further characterize stenosis severity or mechanism of regurgitation, and for ruling out abscess. (↑)
1. In patients with suspected dilated cardiomyopathy, we recommend TTE as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected dilated cardiomyopathy - Evaluate for ischemic cause
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy is a possibility, we recommend invasive catheter angiography for further evaluation. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected dilated cardiomyopathy - Alternative to invasive angiography
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If invasive catheter angiography is unavailable, we recommend CCTA as an alternative. (↑↑)

↪ 1.3 If there is no significant obstructive coronary artery disease based on invasive catheter angiography or CCTA results and further imaging is required, we recommend cardiac MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected dilated cardiomyopathy - Alternative to cardiac MRI
options.t: ↪ 1.4 If information about ventricular size and function is required (and if ventricular size/function is unreliable by TTE) and cardiac MRI is not tolerated, is unavailable, or is contraindicated, we recommend cardiac CT. (↑↑)
↪ 1.5 If cardiac CT is not available, we suggest NM (MUGA). NM (myocardial perfusion scan) may also be helpful to exclude significant ischemia as a cause of dilated cardiomyopathy. (↑)
1. In patients with suspected hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, we recommend TTE as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

↪ 1.1 If further imaging is required, we recommend cardiac MRI as the next imaging modality. MRI can be helpful when echocardiography is inconclusive, when other diagnoses are possible (e.g., amyloidosis, athlete’s heart, storage disease, etc.), or when information about maximum wall thickness, ejection fraction, presence of apical aneurysm or extent of late gadolinium enhancement will influence decision to insert an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected hypertrophic cardiomyopathy - Alternative to cardiac MRI
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If information about ventricular size and function or maximum wall thickness is required AND cardiac MRI is not tolerated, is unavailable, or is contraindicated, we recommend cardiac CT. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected hypertrophic cardiomyopathy - Evaluate for coronary artery disease
options.t: ↪ 1.3 To rule out obstructive coronary artery disease as a cause of patient symptoms, we recommend invasive catheter angiography in carefully selected patients. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected hypertrophic cardiomyopathy - Alternative to invasive angiography
options.t: ↪ 1.4 If invasive catheter angiography is unavailable, we recommend CCTA as an alternative. (↑↑)
1. In patients with suspected restrictive/infiltrative cardiomyopathy, we recommend TTE as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If further imaging is required, we recommend cardiac MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected restrictive/infiltrative cardiomyopathy - Alternative to cardiac MRI
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If information about ventricular size and function is required and cardiac MRI is not tolerated, is unavailable, or is contraindicated, we recommend cardiac CT. (↑↑)
↪ 1.3 In patients with suspected cardiac sarcoidosis, we recommend FDG-PET-CT. (↑↑)
↪ 1.4 In patients with suspected cardiac amyloidosis, if further imaging is required, we recommend NM (pyrophosphate scan) as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
1. In patients with suspected arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy, we recommend TTE as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If further imaging is required, we recommend cardiac MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy - Alternative to cardiac MRI
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If information about ventricular size and function is required and cardiac MRI is not tolerated, is unavailable, or is contraindicated, we recommend cardiac CT. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy - Evaluate for coronary artery disease
options.t: ↪ 1.3 If obstructive coronary artery disease needs to be ruled out as the cause for arrhythmia, we recommend invasive catheter angiography. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy - Alternative to invasive angiography
options.t: ↪ 1.4 If invasive catheter angiography is unavailable, we recommend CCTA as an alternative. (↑↑)

1. In patients with thoracic aortic aneurysm identified by TTE, we recommend chest CTA (preferably cardiac-gated) for baseline measurement and surveillance. In younger patients with thoraco-abdominal aortic aneurysm identified by TTE, MRA may be performed for baseline measurement and surveillance. Surgical consultation could be considered for aortas >4.5 cm in size. (↑↑)
2. In patients without underlying aortopathy with suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) based on physical examination, we recommend US as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 2.1 If US demonstrates aortic diameter between 2.5 and 3.0 cm, we suggest re-evaluation with US after 10 years. (↑↑)
↪ 2.2 If US demonstrates aortic diameter between 3.0 and 3.9 cm, we recommend repeat US at 3-year intervals. (↑↑)

↪ 2.3 If US demonstrates aortic diameter between 4.0 and 4.9 cm, we recommend annual surveillance with US or CT. Surgical consultation could be considered for aortas >4.5 cm in size. For detailed recommendations for patients with underlying aortopathies and sex specific recommendations, see ACC/AHA guideline [30]. (↑↑)
3. In patients with symptoms suspected to be related to thoraco-abdominal aneurysm, we recommend CT with contrast. (↑↑)
1. In patients with suspected vasculitis involving the aorta (i.e., aortitis), we recommend MRA for baseline measurement and surveillance, especially in young patients. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If MRA is not tolerated, is unavailable, or is contraindicated, we recommend CTA for baseline measurement and surveillance. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected aortitis - Further imaging if inconclusive
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If MRA or CTA results are inconclusive regarding disease activity, we suggest FDG-PET-CT or MR-PET. (↑)

options.v: Suspected deep vein thrombosis - Low pre-test probability and negative D-dimer
options.t: 1. In patients with suspected deep vein thrombosis with low pre-test probability (as determined by a structured risk assessment tool) AND negative D-dimer, we recommend no imaging. (↓↓)

options.v: Suspected deep vein thrombosis - D-dimer unavailable
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If D-dimer is unavailable, we recommend interim therapeutic anticoagulation and Doppler US. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected deep vein thrombosis - Further imaging if inconclusive
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If US is inconclusive or of poor quality and further imaging is required, we recommend CTV or MRV as the next imaging modality, with preference for MRV in younger patients. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected deep vein thrombosis - Intermediate/high pre-test probability or positive D-dimer
options.t: 2. In patients with suspected deep vein thrombosis based with intermediate/high pre-test probability (as determined by a structured risk assessment tool) and/or positive D-dimer, we recommend Doppler US as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
3. In patients with superficial venous thrombosis, we suggest Doppler US as the initial imaging modality. (↑)

1. In patients with suspected upper or lower extremity peripheral vascular (arterial) disease based on symptoms or other clinical features and an abnormal ankle-brachial index (ABI < 0.9), we recommend Doppler US for further evaluation. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 If further imaging is required, we recommend CTA or MRA as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Established peripheral arterial disease - Recurrent symptoms
options.t: 2. In patients with established upper or lower extremity peripheral vascular (arterial) disease with recurrent symptoms, we recommend CTA or MRA as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

1. In patients with suspected vascular malformation, to further characterize and guide further management, we recommend time-resolved MRA as the initial imaging modality. In patients presenting with an extremity mass and suspected vascular malformation, Doppler US could be performed as the initial test. (↑↑)

options.v: Vascular malformation - Alternative to time-resolved MRA
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If MRA is not tolerated, is unavailable, or is contraindicated, we recommend CTA as an alternative. (↑↑)
↪ 1.2 To guide further management for high flow vascular malformations, we recommend invasive catheter angiography. (↑↑)
1. In patients with entrapment and compression syndromes involving the extremities where venous thrombosis is also of concern, we recommend Doppler US as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Entrapment/compression syndrome - Further imaging if inconclusive
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If Doppler US is negative or indeterminate and additional imaging is required, we recommend MRA as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.2 If MRA is not tolerated, is unavailable, or is contraindicated, we recommend CTA as an alternative. (↑↑)

options.v: Pre-employment screening - Routine chest X-ray not recommended
options.t: 1. For most individuals we recommend against routine chest XR for pre-employment screening, except in specific circumstances (see Recommendation 2). (↓↓)

options.v: Pre-employment screening - Chest X-ray for high-risk or certain occupations
options.t: 2. In individuals at high-risk for tuberculosis or in certain occupations (e.g., deep water divers), we recommend routine chest XR if one has not been done recently. (↑↑)

options.v: Pre-employment screening - Chest X-ray for positive TB test
options.t: 3. In individuals with positive latent tuberculosis testing, we recommend chest XR to exclude active tuberculosis. (↑↑)

1. In asymptomatic individuals who have had occupational exposure to asbestos and require imaging for documentation or confirmation of injury, we recommend chest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Asbestos exposure - High-resolution CT if chest X-ray equivocal
options.t: ↪ 1.1 In individuals with equivocal chest XR and/or a high clinical suspicion for occupational lung disease, we recommend high-resolution CT as the next imaging modality. (EPc)

options.v: Inpatients - Routine chest X-ray not recommended
options.t: 1. In in-patients, we recommend against routine chest XR. (EPc)

options.v: Non-specific chest pain - Chest X-ray as initial imaging
options.t: 1. In stable patients where imaging is clinically or biochemically indicated, we recommend chest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Non-specific chest pain - Further investigation guided by clinical evaluation
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If the chest XR is normal or equivocal, we suggest that further investigations should be guided after clinical consideration of etiology. (꙳)

options.v: Admitted for non-thoracic conditions - Routine chest X-ray not recommended
options.t: 1. In patients being admitted to hospital for non-thoracic conditions, we recommend against routine chest XR. (↓↓)

options.v: Long-term care admission - Follow local practice guidelines
options.t: 1. In individuals who are being admitted to long-term care, we recommend referring to the local practice guidelines. (↑↑)

options.v: Pre-op non-cardiothoracic surgery - Routine chest X-ray not suggested
options.t: 1. In patients undergoing non-cardiothoracic surgery, we suggest against routine pre-operative chest XR. (↓)

options.v: Pre-op cardiothoracic surgery - Routine chest X-ray suggested
options.t: 2. In patients undergoing cardiothoracic surgery, we suggest routine pre-operative chest XR. (↑)

options.v: Pre-op for frail elderly or cardiorespiratory disease - Routine chest X-ray suggested
options.t: 3. In frail elderly patients and in those with significant cardiorespiratory disease, we suggest routine pre-operative chest XR. (↑)

options.v: Post-chest procedure - Routine chest X-ray suggested in some situations
options.t: 1. In patients who have undergone a chest procedure, including cardiothoracic surgery, we suggest routine post-interventional chest XR in situations where clinical judgement may not be sensitive to potential complications, including post transthoracic interventions (e.g., lung biopsy, central line, nasogastric tube, endotracheal tube placement, thoracentesis, chest tube, etc.). (↑)

options.v: Uncomplicated upper respiratory infection - Chest X-ray not recommended
options.t: 1. In patients with uncomplicated upper respiratory tract infection, we recommend against chest XR. (↓↓)
2. In patients with clinical suspicion of pneumonia, acute tracheobronchitis with other comorbid conditions, we suggest chest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑)
1. In patients with acute asthma exacerbation without clinical concern for complications, we suggest against chest XR. (↓)
2. In patients with acute asthma exacerbation with clinical concern for complications꙳, we recommend chest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Acute COPD exacerbation without hospital referral
options.t: 1. In patients with acute exacerbation of COPD who do not need a referral to hospital, we suggest against routine chest XR. (↓)

options.v: Acute COPD exacerbation with hospital referral
options.t: 2. In patients with acute exacerbation of COPD who are referred to hospital, we recommend chest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Acute COPD exacerbation with negative or indeterminate X-Ray
options.t: ↪ 2.1 In situations where chest XR is negative or indeterminate where there is persistent clinical concern or management might be altered, we suggest chest CT as the next imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: Suspected pneumonia with high pre-test probability
options.t: 1. In stable outpatients with suspected pneumonia with a very high pre-test probability of pneumonia and when a chest XR would not alter management, we suggest against chest XR. (↓)

options.v: Suspected pneumonia with abnormal vital signs
options.t: 2. In patients with abnormal vital signs secondary to suspected pneumonia, we recommend chest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 2.1 In patients with severe or complicated pneumonia (e.g., lung abscess, suspected empyema, or possible atypical organisms), we suggest chest CT as the next imaging modality. (↑)
1. In patients with clinical recovery of pneumonia, we do not recommend follow-up chest XR. (↓↓)

options.v: Pneumonia with persistent symptoms or risk factors
options.t: 2. In patients with persistent symptoms or physical signs of pneumonia or in those at higher risk of malignancy꙳, we suggest follow-up chest XR at least six weeks after treatment. (↑)

options.v: Pneumonia with no resolution within expected time
options.t: ↪ 2.1 In patients with no radiological or clinical resolution of pneumonia within the expected time (e.g., 8-12 weeks), we suggest chest CT as the next imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: Immunosuppressed patient with respiratory symptoms/febrile neutropenia

options.t: 1. In immunosuppressed patients with respiratory symptoms/febrile neutropenia, we recommend chest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Immunosuppressed with normal X-Ray and high clinical suspicion
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If chest XR is normal, equivocal, or inconclusive and there remains high clinical suspicion for pulmonary infection, we recommend low-dose chest CT as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Chronic cough with normal exam and X-Ray
options.t: 1. In patients with chronic cough, we recommend chest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Chronic cough with normal exam and X-Ray, no cause identified
options.t: ↪ 1.1 In patients with normal physical exam and chest XR, we suggest against routine chest CT. (↓)

options.v: Chronic cough with normal exam and X-Ray, suspected underlying condition
options.t: ↪ 1.2 In patients with normal physical exam and chest XR and common causes of chronic cough have been excluded but there is ongoing clinical concern for etiology such as bronchiectasis, early interstitial lung disease, or lung cancer, we suggest chest CT as the next imaging modality. (↑)
1. In patients with suspected pneumothorax, we recommend erect inspiratory chest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Pneumothorax with equivocal or indeterminate X-Ray
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If chest XR findings are equivocal or indeterminate and further imaging is required, we suggest chest CT as the next imaging modality. (↑)
1. In patients with clinically suspected pleural effusion, we recommend chest XR or bedside US (if available) as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Clinically suspected pleural effusion, further imaging required
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If further imaging is required, we suggest chest CT as the next imaging modality. (↑)
1. In patients with trace hemoptysis, we recommend chest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Trace hemoptysis with risk factors or persistent/recurrent
options.t: ↪ 1.1 In patients with risk factors꙳ or persistent/recurrent unexplained hemoptysis, we recommend chest CT as a complementary imaging modality. (↑↑)
2. In patients with clinically significant hemoptysis, we recommend chest XR* and chest CT as the initial imaging modalities. (↑↑)
1. In patients with chronic dyspnea of non-cardiovascular origin, we recommend chest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Chronic dyspnea with normal X-Ray and ongoing clinical concern
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If chest XR is normal and clinical concern remains, any decision for further imaging should be based on clinical grounds. (EPc)
1. In patients with suspected interstitial lung disease, we recommend chest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected interstitial lung disease, further imaging required
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If further imaging is required, given that chest XR do not rule out interstitial lung disease, we recommend high-resolution CT (HRCT) as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

1. In patients with an incidental lung nodule detected on chest CT꙳, we recommend following the Fleischner Society Guidelines for Management of Incidental Pulmonary Nodules Detected on CT Images. Fleischner Society Guidelines: https://doi.org/10.1148/radiol.2017161659 (↑↑)
1. In patients with suspected mediastinal lesion, we recommend chest CT as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected mediastinal lesion, further imaging required
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If further imaging is required to evaluate local invasion or to characterize tissue composition, we recommend chest MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)
1. In patients with suspected mediastinal lymphadenopathy, we recommend chest CT as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Elevated diaphragm on CXR, suspected phrenic nerve palsy
options.t: 1. In patients with elevated diaphragm on chest XR and suspected phrenic nerve palsy, we suggest fluoroscopy or US as the initial imaging modality. The imaging modality may vary based on regional practice preferences and resource availability. (↑)
1. In patients with dysphagia, we suggest fluoroscopy (esophagram or upper GI series) as the initial imaging modality. (↑)
2. In patients with dyspepsia of unknown cause, we suggest fluoroscopy upper GI series as the initial imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: Dyspepsia with suspected gastric motility abnormality
options.t: 3. In patients with dyspepsia if there is clinical suspicion of abnormal gastric motility, we suggest NM scintigraphy (gastric emptying) as the initial imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: Acute nonlocalized abdominal pain, suspected uncomplicated infectious colitis
options.t: 1. In patients with suspected uncomplicated acute infectious colitis presenting with acute nonlocalized abdominal pain, we recommend against imaging in the absence of other concerning clinical and/or biochemical findings. (↓↓)

options.v: Acute nonlocalized abdominal pain in non-pregnant patients
options.t: 2. In non-pregnant patients with acute nonlocalized abdominal pain and/or bowel obstruction, we suggest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: Acute nonlocalized abdominal pain, equivocal or inconclusive X-Ray
options.t: ↪ 2.1 If XR is equivocal and/or further investigation is required, we recommend CT abdomen and pelvis as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Acute nonlocalized abdominal pain in pregnant patients
options.t: 3. In pregnant patients with acute nonlocalized abdominal pain, we recommend US abdomen and pelvis as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Epigastric pain with probable esophageal or gastric etiology
options.t: 1. In patients with epigastric pain with probable esophageal or gastric etiology, we suggest fluoroscopy upper GI series as the initial imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: Epigastric pain without upper GI etiology
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If upper GI series is not available, we suggest a CT abdomen and pelvis. (↑)

options.v: Epigastric pain without probable esophageal or gastric etiology
options.t: 2. In patients with epigastric pain without probable esophageal or gastric etiology, we suggest a CT abdomen and pelvis as the initial imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: Right upper quadrant pain, suspected hepatobiliary disease
options.t: 1. In patients with right upper quadrant pain (suspected hepatobiliary disease), we recommend against XR. (↓↓)

options.v: Right upper quadrant pain, suspected hepatobiliary disease
options.t: 2. In patients with right upper quadrant pain (suspected hepatobiliary disease), we recommend US abdomen as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Right upper quadrant pain, suspected hepatobiliary disease, equivocal ultrasound
options.t: ↪ 2.1 If US is not available or further investigation is required, we suggest CT abdomen and pelvis or NM (HIDA scan) as the next imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: Right upper quadrant pain, suspected choledocolithiasis, equivocal ultrasound
options.t: ↪ 2.2 If US is indeterminate and the clinical/biochemical presentation is strongly suggestive of choledocolithiasis, we suggest consultation for endoscopic US/ERCP and/or MRCP. (↑)

options.v: Right upper quadrant pain, non-hepatobiliary disease
options.t: 3. In patients with right upper quadrant pain (non-hepatobiliary disease), we recommend US abdomen as the initial imaging modality. (EPc)

options.v: Right upper quadrant pain, non-hepatobiliary disease, equivocal ultrasound
options.t: ↪ 3.1 If US is indeterminate, we suggest CT abdomen and pelvis as the next imaging modality. (EPc)

options.v: Right upper quadrant pain, non-hepatobiliary disease, ultrasound and CT unavailable
options.t: ↪ 3.2 If US and CT are not immediately available, we suggest XR as the initial imaging modality. (EPc)

options.v: Right lower quadrant pain in younger patients
options.t: 1. In younger patients with right lower quadrant pain, we recommend US as the initial imaging modality, as per ALARA principles. (↑↑)

options.v: Right lower quadrant pain in non-pregnant younger patients, negative or inconclusive ultrasound
options.t: ↪ 1.1 In non-pregnant patients, if US is negative for appendicitis or inconclusive and further imaging is required, we suggest CT abdomen and pelvis as the next imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: Right lower quadrant pain in pregnant patients, inconclusive ultrasound
options.t: ↪ 1.2 In pregnant patients, if US is inconclusive for appendicitis, we recommend MR abdomen and pelvis as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Right lower quadrant pain in older patients
options.t: 2. In older patients with right lower quadrant pain, we recommend CT abdomen and pelvis as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Left upper quadrant pain, concern for reflux or ulcer
options.t: 1. In patients with left upper quadrant pain (concern for reflux or ulcer), we suggest against fluoroscopic upper GI series. (↓)

options.v: Left upper quadrant pain, unknown etiology
options.t: 2. In patients with left upper quadrant pain (unknown etiology), we recommend US abdomen as the initial imaging modality. (EPc)

options.v: Left upper quadrant pain, unknown etiology, equivocal ultrasound
options.t: ↪ 2.1 If US is indeterminate, we suggest CT abdomen and pelvis as the next imaging modality. (EPc)

options.v: Left upper quadrant pain, unknown etiology, ultrasound and CT unavailable
options.t: ↪ 2.2 If US and CT are not immediately available, we suggest XR as the initial imaging modality. (EPc)

options.v: Left lower quadrant pain, suspected diverticulitis
options.t: 1. In patients with left lower quadrant pain (suspected diverticulitis), we recommend CT abdomen and pelvis as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Left lower quadrant pain, other intraabdominal cause
options.t: 2. In patients with left lower quadrant pain (other intraabdominal cause), we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality. (EPc)

options.v: Left lower quadrant pain, other cause, negative or inconclusive X-Ray
options.t: ↪ 2.1 If XR is negative or indeterminate and further imaging is required, we suggest CT abdomen and pelvis as the next imaging modality. (EPc)

options.v: Left lower quadrant pain, other cause in younger patients or CT contraindicated
options.t: ↪ 2.2 In younger patients or if CT is contraindicated, we suggest US as the next imaging modality. (EPc)

options.v: Chronic abdominal pain meeting IBS criteria
options.t: 1. In patients who meet the diagnostic criteria for irritable bowel syndrome, we recommend against imaging in the absence of concerning clinical and/or biochemical findings. (↓↓)

options.v: Chronic abdominal pain, MRI not recommended
options.t: 2. In patients with chronic abdominal pain, we recommend against MRI as an imaging modality due to limited sensitivity and specificity. (EPc)
3. In patients with chronic abdominal pain, we recommend CT abdomen and pelvis as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Chronic abdominal pain, ultrasound alternative if CT unavailable
options.t: ↪ 3.1 If CT is unavailable, we suggest US abdomen as an alternative imaging modality, accepting its limited scope of assessment compared to CT. (↑)

options.v: Chronic abdominal pain, suspected chronic mesenteric ischemia
options.t: 4. In patients with chronic abdominal pain (suspected chronic mesenteric ischemia), we recommend CTA abdomen and pelvis as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
1. In endoscopy-negative patients with suspected inflammatory bowel disease, we recommend against fluoroscopy small bowel follow through. (↓↓)

options.v: Suspected inflammatory bowel disease in younger patients
options.t: 2. In younger patients with suspected inflammatory bowel disease, we recommend MR enterography as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected inflammatory bowel disease in younger patients, MR enterography contraindicated or unavailable
options.t: ↪ 2.1 If MR enterography is contraindicated or unavailable, we suggest CT enterography. (↑)

options.v: Suspected inflammatory bowel disease in older patients
options.t: 3. In older patients with suspected inflammatory bowel disease, we recommend CT enterography as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected inflammatory bowel disease in older patients, CT enterography intolerant
options.t: ↪ 3.1 If CT enterography cannot be tolerated, we suggest CT abdomen and pelvis. (↑)

options.v: Acute exacerbation of inflammatory bowel disease in younger patients
options.t: 4. In younger patients with suspected acute exacerbation of known inflammatory bowel disease, we recommend MR enterography as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Acute exacerbation of inflammatory bowel disease in younger patients, MR/CT enterography unavailable
options.t: ↪ 4.1 If MR enterography is contraindicated or unavailable, we suggest CT enterography. (↑)

options.v: Acute exacerbation of inflammatory bowel disease in younger patients, MR/CT enterography intolerant
options.t: ↪ 4.2 If MR/CT enterography cannot be tolerated, we recommend CT abdomen and pelvis. (↑↑)

options.v: Acute exacerbation of inflammatory bowel disease in older patients
options.t: 5. In older patients with inflammatory bowel disease with suspected acute exacerbation, we recommend CT enterography as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Acute exacerbation of inflammatory bowel disease in older patients, CT enterography intolerant
options.t: ↪ 5.1 If CT enterography cannot be tolerated, we recommend CT abdomen and pelvis. (↑↑)
1. In patients with acute upper GI bleeding, we recommend CTA or Diagnostic angiography as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
1. In patients with acute lower GI bleeding, we recommend CTA or Diagnostic angiography as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Acute lower GI bleeding, negative CTA
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If CTA is negative or inconclusive, we suggest NM scintigraphy (RBC scan). (↑)

options.v: Chronic GI bleeding, MR enterography not recommended
options.t: 1. In patients with suspected chronic GI bleeding, we suggest against routine use of MR enterography due to limited spatial resolution. (↓)
2. In patients with suspected chronic GI bleeding, we recommend CT enterography as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Chronic GI bleeding, CT enterography intolerant
options.t: ↪ 2.1 If CT enterography cannot be tolerated, we suggest CT abdomen and pelvis. (↑)

options.v: Chronic GI bleeding, negative CT enterography
options.t: ↪ 2.2 If CT enterography is negative and further investigation is required, we suggest NM scintigraphy (RBC and/or Meckel's study) ± capsule endoscopy as the next imaging modality. (↑)
1. In patients with acute abnormal liver biochemistry, we recommend US abdomen as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Acute abnormal liver biochemistry, CT/MRI if ultrasound inconclusive
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If US is inconclusive or if further investigation is required, we suggest CT abdomen or MR abdomen (equivalent alternatives) as the next imaging modality. (↑)

1. In patients with chronic abnormal liver biochemistry, we recommend US abdomen as the initial imaging modality, ideally with the use of a high frequency linear probe to assess the hepatic surface. (↑↑)

options.v: Chronic abnormal liver biochemistry, MRI if further investigation required
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If further investigation is required, we recommend MR abdomen as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Chronic abnormal liver biochemistry, CT if MRI unavailable
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If MR abdomen is contraindicated or unavailable, we suggest CT abdomen. (↑)

options.v: Chronic abnormal liver biochemistry, ultrasound with shear wave elastography
options.t: 2. In noncirrhotic patients with chronic abnormal liver biochemistry, if available, we suggest US shear wave elastography in addition to US abdomen to diagnose, follow, or stage occult hepatic fibrosis. (↑)

options.v: Chronic abnormal liver biochemistry, MR elastography if ultrasound inconclusive
options.t: ↪ 2.1 If US shear wave elastography is not available or inconclusive and imaging is required, we suggest MR elastography. (↑)

options.v: Acute pancreatitis, no imaging for diagnosis
options.t: 1. As per the revised Atlanta Criteria, in patients who meet the diagnostic criteria for acute pancreatitis, we recommend against imaging for the purpose of diagnosis. (↓↓)

options.v: Acute pancreatitis due to gallstones, ultrasound
options.t: 2. In patients with suspected acute pancreatitis due to gallstones, we recommend US abdomen as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Acute pancreatitis, MRI if further investigation required
options.t: ↪ 2.1 If further investigation is required, we recommend MR abdomen with MRCP as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Complicated acute pancreatitis, imaging per guidelines
options.t: 3. In patients with suspected complicated sub-acute pancreatitis, we recommend imaging as per the revised Atlanta Criteria. (↑↑)
1. In patients with suspected chronic pancreatitis, we recommend CT abdomen as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Chronic pancreatitis, GI referral if CT negative
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If CT is negative, we suggest GI referral ± endoscopic US. (↑)
2. In patients with known chronic pancreatitis, we recommend MR abdomen with MRCP for any required follow-up imaging. (↑↑)

options.v: Known chronic pancreatitis, CT if MRI unavailable
options.t: ↪ 2.1 If MR abdomen is contraindicated or unavailable, we suggest CT abdomen. (↑)
1. In patients with suspected perianal fistula, we recommend against CT pelvis. (↓↓)
2. In patients with suspected perianal fistula, we recommend MR pelvis as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected perianal fistula, endoanal ultrasound if MRI unavailable
options.t: ↪ 2.1 If MRI is not available or contraindicated, we suggest endoanal US as an alternative imaging modality. (↑)
3. In patients with suspected perianal abscess, we recommend MR pelvis as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected perianal abscess, endoanal ultrasound if MRI unavailable
options.t: ↪ 3.1 If MRI is not available or contraindicated, we suggest endoanal US as an alternative imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: Large perianal abscess, CT if MRI/US unavailable
options.t: ↪ 3.2 In patients with suspected large perianal abscess, if MRI or US is not available or contraindicated, we suggest CT pelvis as an alternative imaging modality. (↑)
4. In patients with suspected anovesicular or anovaginal fistula, we recommend CT pelvis. (↑↑)
↪ 4.1 In patients with suspected anovesicular or anovaginal fistula, we suggest MR pelvis as an alternative imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: Uncomplicated acute infectious colitis, no imaging
options.t: 1. In patients with suspected uncomplicated acute infectious colitis presenting with acute nonlocalized abdominal pain, we recommend against imaging in the absence of other concerning clinical and/or biochemical findings. (↓↓)
2. In patients with diarrhea (unknown cause), we suggest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑)
↪ 2.1 If XR is inconclusive, we suggest specialist consultation (e.g., gastroenterology, general surgery) and/or CT abdomen and pelvis. (↑)

options.v: Fecal incontinence with constipation, no imaging
options.t: 1. In patients with fecal incontinence (clinically diagnosed constipation), we recommend against imaging in the absence of other concerning clinical and/or biochemical findings. (↓↓)
2. In patients with fecal incontinence (clinically indeterminate for constipation), we suggest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: Fecal incontinence, suspected cauda equina, MRI
options.t: 3. In patients with fecal incontinence (suspected cauda equina), we recommend MR lumbar spine as the initial imaging modality. (EPc)

options.v: Fecal incontinence, suspected pelvic floor dysfunction, dynamic MRI
options.t: 4. In patients with fecal incontinence (suspected pelvic floor dysfunction), we suggest dynamic MR pelvic floor. (EPc)

options.v: Fecal incontinence, pelvic floor dysfunction, fluoroscopic defecography if MRI unavailable
options.t: ↪ 4.1 If MRI is not available or contraindicated, we suggest fluoroscopic defecography. (EPc)
1. In patients with suspected or known foreign body ingestion, we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Foreign body ingestion, CT if X-Ray concerning
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If XR is suspicious for obstruction or perforation, we suggest CT abdomen and pelvis as the next imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: Foreign body ingestion, CT if X-Ray negative and further management needed
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If XR is negative and additional management is being considered, we suggest CT abdomen and pelvis as the next imaging modality. (↑)
1. In patients with suspected pregnancy, we recommend against US for pregnancy confirmation. (↓↓)

2. In patients in the 1st trimester with confirmed intrauterine pregnancy, we recommend transabdominal US as the initial imaging modality for the following: pregnancy dating, to assess fetal number, chorionicity and amnionicity in multiple gestations, measurement of nuchal translucency (in single and multiple gestations), screening for select major anatomical abnormalities (such as anencephaly), and in patients with suspected complications of early pregnancy. (↑↑)

options.v: Transvaginal ultrasound if transabdominal is suboptimal
options.t: ↪ 2.1 If transabdominal US is indeterminate or suboptimal for these clinical indications, we recommend transvaginal US as an adjunct. (↑↑)

options.v: No Doppler without clinical indication in 1st trimester
options.t: 3. In patients in the 1st trimester with a viable or potentially viable intrauterine pregnancy, we suggest not using Doppler as an adjunct to US without a clear clinical indication. (↓)

options.v: Combined transabdominal and transvaginal ultrasound for suspected ectopic or pregnancy of unknown location
options.t: 4. In patients in the 1st trimester with a positive pregnancy test and a suspected PUL or ectopic pregnancy, we recommend a combined transabdominal and transvaginal US approach as the initial imaging technique. The uterus should be thoroughly scanned for the presence of a gestational sac, and in its absence, then the adnexa should be thoroughly scanned for the presence of a mass. (↑↑)

options.v: Repeat ultrasound if initial results are inconclusive
options.t: ↪ 4.1 If results are initially inconclusive, we recommend close clinical and biochemical assessment with follow-up repeat US assessment. (↑↑)

options.v: Transabdominal ultrasound for routine 2nd trimester screening
options.t: 1. In patients in the 2nd trimester of pregnancy, typically between 18-20 weeks, we recommend routine screening with transabdominal US, for evaluation of fetal anatomy, fetal growth, and general assessment of the placenta. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 Where indicated, in the evaluation of fetal growth and well-being, characterization of complex anatomy, and placental and cord assessment, we recommend Doppler as an adjunct. (↑↑)
↪ 1.2 For complex fetal conditions, if US is indeterminate or if further investigation is required, we suggest MRI. Timing of the MRI may be determined based on clinical indication. (↑)

options.v: Combined transabdominal and transvaginal ultrasound for suspected low-lying or invasive placenta
options.t: 2. In patients in the 2nd trimester of pregnancy with suspected low location of the placenta or invasive placentation, we recommend a combined transabdominal and transvaginal US approach. (↑↑)
↪ 2.1 We recommend Doppler as an adjunct. (↑↑)
↪ 2.2 For suspected invasive placentation, if US is indeterminate or if further investigation is required, we suggest MRI. (↑)

options.v: Transvaginal ultrasound for cervical assessment in high-risk pregnancies
options.t: 3. In patients in the 2nd trimester with a history of pre-term birth, or with other risk factors for pre-term birth, and in patients with suspected preterm labour, we recommend transvaginal US for assessment of the cervix. (↑↑)

options.v: Transperineal ultrasound if transvaginal is not feasible
options.t: ↪ 3.1 If transvaginal US is declined or is not feasible, we recommend transperineal US as an alternative. (↑↑)

options.v: Combined transabdominal and transvaginal ultrasound for 2nd trimester vaginal bleeding
options.t: 4. In patients in the 2nd trimester experiencing vaginal bleeding, we recommend a combined transabdominal and transvaginal US approach. (↑↑)
↪ 4.1 We recommend Doppler as an adjunct. (↑↑)

options.v: Fetal echocardiography if indicated after routine anatomy scan
options.t: 5. Following the routine anatomy scan, if risk factors are identified and/or fetal cardiac screening examination is abnormal, we suggest fetal echocardiography US. (↑)

options.v: Transabdominal ultrasound for 3rd trimester assessment if no prior scans
options.t: 1. In patients in the 3rd trimester who have not received a 1st or 2nd trimester diagnostic US, we recommend transabdominal US for general assessment of the pregnancy. (↑↑)

options.v: Doppler and/or transvaginal ultrasound as clinically indicated
options.t: ↪ 1.1 We recommend Doppler and/or transvaginal US as adjuncts, as clinically indicated. (↑↑)

options.v: Transabdominal ultrasound surveillance for high-risk 3rd trimester pregnancies
options.t: 2. In high-risk 3rd trimester pregnancies, including multifetal pregnancy, we recommend transabdominal US surveillance to monitor fetal growth and well-being. (↑↑)

options.v: Doppler and/or transvaginal ultrasound as clinically indicated
options.t: ↪ 2.1 We recommend Doppler and/or transvaginal US as adjuncts, as clinically indicated. (↑↑)
↪ 2.2 For complex fetal conditions, if US is indeterminate or if further investigation is required, we suggest MRI. Timing of the MRI may be determined based on clinical indication. (↑)
