options.v: Transvaginal ultrasound to assess placental location in known low-lying/previa
options.t: 3. In patients diagnosed with low-lying placenta or placenta previa in the 2nd trimester, we recommend a transvaginal US to reassess placental location by the mid-3rd trimester. (↑↑)
↪ 3.1 We recommend Doppler as an adjunct. (↑↑)

options.v: Combined transabdominal and transvaginal ultrasound for suspected invasive placentation
options.t: 4. In patients in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy with suspected invasive placentation, we recommend a combined transabdominal and transvaginal US approach. (↑↑)
↪ 4.1 We recommend Doppler as an adjunct. (↑↑)
↪ 4.2 If further investigation is required, we suggest MRI. (↑)

options.v: Combined transabdominal and transvaginal ultrasound for 3rd trimester vaginal bleeding
options.t: 5. In patients in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy experiencing vaginal bleeding, we recommend a combined transabdominal and transvaginal US approach. (↑↑)
↪ 5.1 We recommend Doppler as an adjunct. (↑↑)

options.v: Combined transabdominal and transvaginal ultrasound for postpartum hemorrhage
options.t: 1. In patients with early and/or late post-partum hemorrhage, we recommend a combined transabdominal and transvaginal US approach as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 We recommend Doppler as an adjunct. (↑↑)
↪ 1.2 If US is indeterminate or further investigation is required, we suggest MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: Clinical observation with ultrasound if MRI is unavailable
options.t: ↪ 1.3 If MRI is unavailable or contraindicated, we suggest close clinical observation with follow-up transabdominal and transvaginal US. (EPc)

options.v: CT for suspected intraabdominal bleeding with postpartum hemorrhage
options.t: 2. In patients with early and/or late post-partum hemorrhage where there is clinical concern for intraabdominal bleeding, we suggest CT to confirm, localize, and assess for the presence of active bleeding. (↑)

options.v: Combined transabdominal and transvaginal ultrasound for postpartum infection
options.t: 3. In patients with suspected or confirmed post-partum infection, we recommend combined transabdominal and transvaginal US approach as the initial imaging modality to exclude retained products of conception and assess for complications of infection. (↑↑)

options.v: CT or MRI if ultrasound is indeterminate
options.t: ↪ 3.1 If US is indeterminate or further investigation is required, we suggest CT or MRI as the next imaging modality depending on the clinical situation. (↑)

options.v: Clinical monitoring and follow-up ultrasound if CT/MRI unavailable
options.t: ↪ 3.2 If CT and MRI are unavailable or contraindicated, we suggest close clinical monitoring and follow-up US. (EPc)

options.v: Combined transabdominal and transvaginal ultrasound as initial imaging
options.t: 1. In patients with recurrent 1st trimester pregnancy loss, we recommend a combined transabdominal and transvaginal US approach as the initial imaging technique. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 We suggest Doppler as an adjunct. (↑)

options.v: MRI if ultrasound is negative, indeterminate, or complex abnormalities
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If US is negative, indeterminate, or if additional workup of complex abnormalities identified on US is required, we recommend MRI pelvis as the next imaging technique. (↑↑)

options.v: MRI, 3-D ultrasound, or SIS for suspected Müllerian/intracavitary abnormalities
options.t: 2. In patients with suspected Müllerian duct or intracavitary abnormalities based on initial assessment, we suggest MRI, 3-D US, or SIS for further characterization. (↑)

options.v: Transabdominal and/or transvaginal ultrasound as initial imaging
options.t: 1. In patients with infertility, we recommend transabdominal US and/or transvaginal US as the initial imaging technique. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 We suggest Doppler as an adjunct. (↑)

options.v: 3-D ultrasound, SIS, or MRI if ultrasound of endometrium is indeterminate
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If initial assessment by US is indeterminate or if additional workup of the endometrium is required, we recommend 3-D US, SIS, or MRI as the next imaging technique. (↑↑)

options.v: MRI if ultrasound assessment of adnexa is indeterminate
options.t: ↪ 1.3 If US assessment of the adnexa is indeterminate or if additional workup of the adnexa is required, we recommend MRI as the next imaging technique. (↑↑)

options.v: SIS or HSG for tubal patency assessment
options.t: 2. In patients with infertility, for the assessment of tubal patency, we recommend SIS or HSG. (↑↑)

options.v: Ultrasound to assess for varicocele in male infertility
options.t: 3. In the investigation of the male factor infertility, we recommend US as the initial imaging technique to assess for varicoceles. (↑↑)

options.v: Combined transabdominal and transvaginal ultrasound as initial imaging
options.t: 1. In patients with suspected adnexal mass with no acute symptoms, we recommend a combined transabdominal and transvaginal US approach as the initial imaging technique. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 We recommend Doppler as an adjunct. (↑↑)
↪ 1.2 If US is indeterminate or further investigation is required, we recommend MRI as the next imaging technique. (↑↑)

options.v: Evaluation of acute pelvic pain of presumed gynecologic origin
Combined transabdominal and transvaginal ultrasound as initial imaging
options.t: 1. In patients with acute pelvic pain of presumed gynecologic origin, we recommend a combined transabdominal and transvaginal US approach as the initial imaging technique. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 We recommend Doppler as an adjunct. (↑↑)

options.v: Repeat combined ultrasound if initial is indeterminate
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If US is indeterminate or further investigation is required and immediate management is not indicated, we recommend follow-up combined transabdominal and transvaginal US approach. (↑↑)

options.v: CT in beta-HCG negative patients if further investigation required
options.t: ↪ 1.3 If further investigation is required, we suggest CT (in beta-HCG negative patients). (↑)

options.v: Pelvic MRI in pregnant patients or for problem-solving
options.t: ↪ 1.4 In pregnant patients and for problem-solving, where indicated, we suggest pelvic MRI. (↑↑)

options.v: Evaluation of chronic pelvic pain of presumed gynecologic origin
Combined transabdominal and transvaginal ultrasound as initial imaging
options.t: 1. In patients with chronic pelvic pain of presumed gynecologic origin, we recommend a combined transabdominal and transvaginal US approach as the initial imaging technique. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 We recommend Doppler as an adjunct. (↑↑)

options.v: CT in beta-HCG negative patients if further investigation required
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If further investigation is required, we suggest CT (in beta-HCG negative patients). (↑)

options.v: Pelvic MRI in pregnant patients or for problem-solving
options.t: ↪ 1.3 In pregnant patients and for problem-solving, where indicated, we suggest pelvic MRI. (↑)

options.v: Combined transabdominal and transvaginal ultrasound as initial imaging
options.t: 1. In patients with abnormal uterine bleeding, we recommend a combined transabdominal and transvaginal US approach as the initial imaging technique. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 We suggest Doppler as an adjunct. (↑)

options.v: SIS if further endometrial investigation required
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If further investigation of the endometrium is required, we recommend SIS as the next imaging technique. (↑↑)

options.v: MRI if sonographic investigations are inconclusive
options.t: ↪ 1.3 If sonographic investigations are inconclusive or unavailable, we recommend MRI. (↑↑)

options.v: No routine ultrasound for ovarian morphology in PCOS
options.t: 2. For patients diagnosed on clinical and biochemical grounds with polycystic ovarian syndrome, we do not recommend the routine use of US for evaluation of ovarian morphology. (↓↓)

options.v: Transvaginal ultrasound if clinical/biochemical indices are equivocal
options.t: ↪ 2.1 If clinical and biochemical indices are equivocal, we recommend transvaginal US to assess ovarian morphology. (↑↑)

options.v: Combined transabdominal and transvaginal ultrasound as initial imaging
options.t: 1. In patients where localization of an intra-uterine contraceptive device (IUCD) is required, we recommend a combined transabdominal and transvaginal US approach as the initial imaging technique. (↑↑)

options.v: 3-D ultrasound as an adjunct if available
options.t: ↪ 1.1 We suggest 3-D US as an adjunct, where available. (↑)

options.v: X-Ray if IUCD not seen on ultrasound
options.t: ↪ 1.2 If IUCD is not seen in the uterus on US, we recommend XR of the abdomen and pelvis as the next imaging technique. (↑↑)

options.v: CT head for acute head trauma in adults meeting imaging criteria
options.t: Acute head trauma in adults

options.v: No X-Ray except as problem-solving tool for head trauma in adults
options.t: 2. In adults who have sustained an acute head injury, we recommend against XR, except as a problem-solving tool (e.g., gunshot wounds). (↓↓)

options.v: CT head for acute head trauma in children meeting imaging criteria
options.t: Acute head trauma in children

options.v: No X-Ray except as problem-solving tool for head trauma in children
options.t: 2. In children who have sustained an acute head injury, we recommend against XR, except as a problem-solving tool (e.g., gunshot wounds, non-accidental trauma) (↓↓)

options.v: No X-Ray for isolated facial trauma
options.t: 2. In patients with isolated facial trauma*, we recommend against XR. (↓↓)

options.v: OPG for suspected mandibular fracture if CT unavailable
options.t: ↪ 2.1 *In patients with suspected mandibular fracture, we suggest OPG if CT is not available. (↑)
1. In patients with orbital trauma, we recommend <b>CT</b> as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Acute orbital trauma: No x-ray unless query metallic foreign body

options.v: Suspected cervical spine trauma in adults
X-Ray if CT is not readily available for low-risk patients
options.t: ↪ 1.1 In low-risk patients, in settings where CT is not readily available, we suggest XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: MRI if persistent concern for ligamentous or spinal cord injury after normal CT

options.v: Suspected cervical spine trauma in children
X-Ray as initial imaging for cervical spine trauma in children at lower risk
options.t: 2. In children with cervical spine trauma who do not meet the patient population in recommendation 1, but may require imaging (e.g., failed a clinical decision rule like PECARN), we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: CT if X-Ray is non-diagnostic or abnormal
options.t: ↪ 2.1 In situations where XR is non-diagnostic and there is persistent clinical concern for cervical spine injury, OR if XR is abnormal, OR if there is clinical-radiologic discrepancy, we recommend CT as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: MRI if persistent concern for ligamentous or spinal cord injury after normal CT
options.t: 3. In children with normal CT of the cervical spine who have persistent suspicion of significant ligamentous or spinal cord injury, we recommend MRI. (↑↑)

options.v: CT angiogram as initial imaging for suspected head/neck vascular injury
options.t: Suspected head and neck vascular injury, including penetrating injury

options.v: X-Ray as initial imaging for suspected thoracolumbar fracture without deficits

options.v: CT as initial imaging for suspected thoracolumbar fracture with deficits
options.t: 2. In patients with suspected thoracolumbar spine fracture with neurological deficits, we recommend CT as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: X-Ray as initial imaging for acute hip and pelvic trauma
options.t: Acute hip and pelvic trauma

options.v: CT if X-Ray is negative but clinical concern persists
options.t: ↪ 1.1 In situations where XR is negative and there is persistent clinical concern for hip and/or pelvic fracture, we recommend CT as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: X-Ray as initial imaging for acute shoulder trauma

options.v: CT if X-Ray is negative or non-diagnostic
options.t: ↪ 1.1 In situations where XR is negative or non-diagnostic and there is persistent clinical concern for bony injury, we suggest CT as the next imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: X-Ray as initial imaging for acute elbow trauma

options.v: CT if X-Ray is negative or non-diagnostic in skeletally mature patients

options.v: Acute hand and wrist trauma: initial imaging
options.t: 1. In patients with acute hand and/or wrist trauma, we recommend XR* as the initial imaging modality. If a dislocation is identified, post-reduction XR should also be performed. (↑↑)

options.v: Acute hand and wrist trauma: next imaging
options.t: ↪ 1.1 In skeletally mature patients, in situations where XR is negative or non-diagnostic and there is persistent clinical concern for bony injury, we suggest CT or MRI as the next imaging modality. (↑)

options.t: ↪ 1.2 If scaphoid fracture is suspected and CT or MR is not available, we recommend immobilization and repeat XR in 10-14 days. (↑↑)

options.v: Acute knee trauma (Ottawa knee rule): initial imaging

↪ 1.1 In situations where XR is negative or non-diagnostic and there is persistent clinical concern for bony injury, we suggest CT as the next imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: Acute ankle trauma (Ottawa ankle rule): initial imaging
options.t: 1. In patients with acute ankle trauma who meet the Ottawa Ankle Rule, we recommend ankle XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 In situations where XR is negative or non-diagnostic and there is persistent clinical concern for bony injury, we suggest CT as the next imaging modality. (↑)
1. In patients with acute foot trauma in whom fracture is suspected, we recommend foot XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 In situations where XR is negative or non-diagnostic and there is persistent clinical concern for bony injury, we suggest CT as the next imaging modality. (↑)

options.v: Superficial soft tissue injury foreign body
Superficial soft tissue injury foreign body: initial imaging
options.t: 1. In patients with suspected superficial soft tissue foreign body, we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Superficial soft tissue injury foreign body: next imaging
options.t: ↪ 1.1 In situations where no foreign body is detected on XR and there is persistent clinical concern for foreign body, we recommend US as the next imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Adult minor chest trauma with low clinical suspicion: no imaging
options.t: 1. In adults with minor chest trauma with a low suspicion of clinically significant injury*, we suggest no imaging. (↓)

options.v: Moderate to severe adult chest trauma: assessment
options.t: 2. In adults with moderate to severe chest trauma, we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality, proceeding to CT if there is any clinical or radiological concern. (↑↑)

options.v: Pediatric minor chest trauma: no imaging
options.t: 1. In children with minor chest trauma and/or where there is low suspicion of clinically significant injury, we suggest no imaging. (↓)

options.v: Pediatric moderate ot severe chest trauma: assessment
options.t: 2. In children with moderate to severe chest trauma, we recommend XR as the initial imaging modality, proceeding to CT if there is any clinical or radiological concern. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected internal abdominal injury: initial imaging
options.t: 1. In adults who have sustained abdominal trauma, in whom internal injury is suspected, we recommend CT as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: Suspected internal abdominal injury: alternative imaging
options.t: ↪ 1.1 In the specific clinical context where CT is not available, we suggest that US be used, while considering its significant limitations. (↑)
2. In adults with suspected bladder injury, following clinical examination and initial abdominal and pelvic CT, we suggest CT cystography. (↑)
1. In children who have sustained abdominal trauma, in whom internal injury is suspected, we recommend CT as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)
↪ 1.1 In the specific clinical context where CT in not available, we suggest that US be used, while considering its significant limitations. (↑)
2. In children with suspected bladder injury, following clinical examination and initial abdominal and pelvic CT, we suggest CT cystography. (↑)

options.v: Skeletal survey X-Ray as initial imaging for suspected non-accidental trauma in children
options.t: 1. In children with suspected non-accidental trauma, we recommend skeletal survey XR as the initial imaging modality. (↑↑)

options.v: CT head for suspected non-accidental head trauma in young children, refer to T02 for older children
options.t: 2. If there is suspicion of non-accidental head trauma, especially in very young children, we suggest CT head. For older children, please refer to T02. Acute head trauma in children. (↑)

options.v: No routine mammography screening for females under 40
options.t: 1. In females younger than 40 years old, at average risk of breast cancer, we recommend against routine mammography screening. (↓↓)
2. In females 40 to 49 years of age, at average risk of breast cancer, we suggest annual mammography/DBT screening. (↑)

options.v: Mammography/DBT screening every 1-2 years for females 50 and older
options.t: 3. In females 50 years of age and older, at average risk of breast cancer, we recommend mammography/DBT screening every one to two years. (↑↑)

options.v: Supplementary imaging for females with extremely dense breast tissue
options.t: 4. In females undergoing screening with mammographically confirmed extremely dense breast tissue (i.e., ACR category D), we suggest supplementary imaging. (↑)

options.v: Supplementary imaging for females with ACR category C dense breast tissue
options.t: ↪ 4.1 In females with mammographically confirmed ACR category C dense breast tissue, we suggest supplementary imaging, depending on capacity constraints. (↑)

options.v: Screening trans people at average risk
No routine mammography/DBT screening for transmasculine under 40 or transfeminine with <5 years hormone use
options.t: 1. In transmasculine people under 40 years of age (with or without bilateral mastectomies) and in transfeminine individuals with no or < 5 years of hormone use, at average risk of breast cancer, we recommend against routine mammography/DBT screening. (↓↓)

options.v: Annual mammography/DBT screening for transmasculine 40-49 without mastectomy
options.t: 2. In transmasculine people at average risk of breast cancer, aged 40 to 49 years of age, who have not undergone bilateral mastectomies, we suggest annual mammography/DBT screening. (↑)

options.v: Mammography/DBT screening every 1-2 years for transmasculine 50+ without mastectomy
options.t: 3. In transmasculine people at average risk of breast cancer, aged 50 years and older, who have not undergone bilateral mastectomies, we recommend mammography/DBT screening every one to two years. (↑↑)

options.v: Annual mammography/DBT screening for transfeminine 40-49 with ≥5 years hormone use
options.t: 4. In transfeminine people at average risk of breast cancer with or without breast implants, aged 40 to 49 years of age, with past or current hormone use for ≥ 5 years, we suggest annual mammography/DBT screening. (↑)

options.v: Mammography/DBT screening every 1-2 years for transfeminine 50+ with ≥5 years hormone use
options.t: 5. In transfeminine people at average risk of breast cancer with or without breast implants, aged 50 years and older, with past or current hormone use for ≥ 5 years, we suggest mammography/DBT screening every one to two years. (↑)

options.v: Annual mammography/DBT and MRI screening for high-risk due to prior chest wall radiation
options.t: 1. In females at high risk of breast cancer due to prior chest wall irradiation between the ages of 10 to 30 years, we recommend annual mammography/DBT and MRI screening starting 8 years after chest irradiation, but not before 25 years of age. (↑↑)

options.v: Ultrasound alternative if MRI is not tolerated, contraindicated, or unavailable
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If MRI is not tolerated, contraindicated, or unavailable, we suggest US as an alternative imaging technique. (↑)

options.v: Annual mammography/DBT and MRI screening for BRCA mutation carriers
options.t: 2. In females with BRCA gene mutations, we recommend annual mammography/DBT and MRI screening, starting between the ages of 25 and 30 years. (↑↑)

options.v: Ultrasound alternative if MRI is not tolerated, contraindicated, or unavailable
options.t: ↪ 2.1 If MRI is not tolerated, contraindicated, or unavailable, we suggest US as an alternative imaging technique. (↑)

options.v: Individualized screening decisions for other high-risk gene mutations
options.t: 3. The role of screening in females with other high-risk gene mutations is an evolving science and further research is required to guide recommendations in this field. Any decision for screening should be made through shared decision making between the physician and the patient. (EPc)

options.v: Annual mammography/DBT and MRI screening for ≥20% lifetime risk
options.t: 4. In females with lifetime risk of ≥20% (based on risk assessment tool), we suggest annual mammography/DBT and supplementary screening, preferably with MRI, starting between the ages of 25 and 30 years. (↑)

options.v: Screening trans people at increased risk
Identical recommendations to B02A for transfeminine ≥30 with ≥5 years hormone use
options.t: 1. In transfeminine people at high risk for breast cancer꙳, aged 30 years and older, with past or current hormone use ≥ 5 years, guideline recommendations are identical to those presented in B02A.

options.v: Identical recommendations to B02A for transmasculine ≥30 without mastectomy
options.t: 2. In transmasculine people at high risk for breast cancer꙳, aged 30 years and older, who have not undergone bilateral mastectomies, guideline recommendations are identical to those presented in B02A.

options.v: Screening pregnant/lactating persons at increased risk
Mammography/DBT and supplemental ultrasound for pregnant high-risk persons
options.t: 1. In pregnant people at high risk of breast cancer who choose to continue screening, we suggest mammography/DBT꙳ screening and supplemental screening with US꙳꙳. (↑)

options.v: Resume annual mammography/DBT and MRI after 1 year for lactating high-risk persons
options.t: 2. In lactating people at high risk of breast cancer who choose to continue screening, we suggest that annual mammography/digital breast tomosynthesis and MRI screening resume after one year. (↑)

options.v: Targeted ultrasound as initial imaging for females under 30 with palpable mass
options.t: 1. In females under 30 years of age with a palpable breast mass, we recommend targeted US of the area of clinical concern as the initial imaging technique. (↑↑)

options.v: No further work-up if ultrasound findings are negative, based on clinical/radiologist discretion
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If US findings are negative, we recommend that any decision for further work-up should be based on radiologist discretion and/or clinical grounds. (EPc)

options.v: Mammography/DBT and targeted ultrasound as initial imaging for females 30+ with palpable mass
options.t: 2. In females 30 years of age and older with a palpable breast mass, we recommend mammography/DBT and targeted US of the area of clinical concern as the initial imaging techniques. (↑↑)

options.v: Further intervention based on clinical grounds if mammography and ultrasound are negative for clinically concerning palpable mass
options.t: 3. In females of any age with a palpable breast mass that is clinically concerning for malignancy, and mammography and US are negative, we recommend that any decision for further intervention (e.g., palpation-guided biopsy, MRI) should be based on clinical grounds. (EPc)

options.v: No imaging for physiological nipple discharge
options.t: 1. In females, at any age, with physiological nipple discharge, we recommend against imaging. (↓↓)

options.v: Targeted ultrasound of retroareolar region as initial imaging for non-physiological nipple discharge in females under 30
options.t: 2. In females under 30 years of age with non-physiological nipple discharge, we recommend targeted US of the retroareolar region as the initial imaging technique. (↑↑)

options.v: Mammography/DBT and targeted ultrasound of retroareolar region as initial imaging for non-physiological nipple discharge in females 30+
options.t: 3. In females 30 years of age and older with non-physiological nipple discharge, we recommend mammography/DBT and targeted US of the retroareolar region as the initial imaging techniques. (↑↑)

options.v: MRI or ductography if mammography and ultrasound are negative or inconclusive
options.t: ↪ 3.1 If the mammography and US are negative or inconclusive, we recommend MRI or ductography as the next imaging technique. (↑↑)

options.v: Further work-up based on clinical grounds if all imaging is negative
options.t: ↪ 3.2 If all imaging is negative, we recommend that any decision for further work-up be based on clinical grounds, with consideration for surgical consult. (EPc)

options.v: Suspected Paget's disease of the breast/nipple
options.t: Suspected Paget’s disease of the breast/nipple

options.v: Mammography/DBT +/- ultrasound as initial imaging for suspected Paget's disease
options.t: 1. In females with clinical suspicion of Paget’s disease, we recommend mammography/DBT +/- US as the initial imaging techniques. (↑↑)

options.v: Further intervention based on clinical grounds if mammography +/- ultrasound are negative but clinical findings remain suspicious
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If mammography +/- US are negative but clinical findings remain suspicious for Paget’s disease, we recommend that any decision for further intervention (e.g., punch biopsy, MRI) should be based on clinical grounds. (EPc)

options.v: Mammography/DBT and ultrasound as initial imaging for suspected inflammatory breast cancer
options.t: 1. In females with clinical suspicion of inflammatory breast cancer꙳, we recommend mammography/DBT and US as the initial imaging techniques. (↑↑)

options.v: Further intervention based on clinical grounds if mammography and ultrasound are negative but clinical findings remain suspicious
options.t: ↪ 1.1 If mammography and US are negative but clinical findings remain suspicious for inflammatory breast cancer, we recommend that any decision for further intervention (e.g., punch biopsy, MRI) should be based on clinical grounds. (EPc)

options.v: Axillary ultrasound as initial imaging for patients under 30 with palpable axillary concern
options.t: 1. In patients under 30 years of age with a palpable area of concern in the axilla, we suggest axillary US as the initial imaging technique. (EPc)

options.v: Axillary ultrasound +/- diagnostic mammography/DBT as initial imaging for patients 30+ with palpable axillary concern
options.t: 2. In patients 30 years of age and older with a palpable area of concern in the axilla, we recommend axillary US ± diagnostic mammography/DBT as the initial imaging techniques. (↑↑)

options.v: No further imaging if bilateral axillary lymphadenopathy and known systemic disease
options.t: ↪ 2.1 In patients with bilateral axillary lymphadenopathy on an otherwise normal mammogram AND systemic disease that is known to account for the lymphadenopathy, we recommend against further imaging. (↓↓)

options.v: Targeted ultrasound as initial imaging for symptomatic pregnant and lactating patients
options.t: 1. In symptomatic pregnant and lactating patients, we recommend targeted US as the initial imaging technique. (↑↑)

options.v: Mammography/DBT as next imaging if ultrasound findings are indeterminate or suspicious
options.t: ↪ 1.1 In patients with US findings that are indeterminate or suspicious, we recommend mammography/DBT as the next imaging technique. (↑↑)

options.v: Further intervention based on clinical grounds if ultrasound and mammography are negative but clinical findings are concerning
options.t: ↪ 1.2 In patients with clinical findings that are concerning for malignancy, and US and mammography are negative, that any decision for further intervention (e.g., palpation-guided biopsy) should be based on clinical grounds. (EPc)

options.v: No imaging for gynecomastia or pseudogynecomastia in males
options.t: 1. In males, of any age, with symptoms and physical examination consistent with gynecomastia or pseudogynecomastia, we recommend against imaging. (↓↓)

options.v: Targeted ultrasound as initial imaging for males under 25 with suspicious findings
options.t: 2. In males under the age of 25 presenting with suspicious physical examination findings꙳, we recommend targeted US as the initial imaging technique. (↑↑)

options.v: Mammography/DBT or ultrasound as initial imaging for males 25+ with suspicious findings
options.t: 3. In males 25 years of age and older, with suspicious physical examination findings꙳, we recommend diagnostic mammography/DBT or US as the initial imaging technique. (↑↑)

options.v: Targeted ultrasound as initial imaging for palpable concern in pediatric/adolescent patients
options.t: 1. In paediatric and adolescent patients presenting with a palpable area of concern, we suggest targeted US as the initial imaging technique. (EPc)

options.v: No mammography for palpable concern in pediatric/adolescent patients
options.t: 2. In paediatric and adolescent patients presenting with a palpable area of concern, we recommend against mammography. (EPc)

options.v: Previous diagnosis of a high-risk lesion
Annual mammography/DBT screening starting at diagnosis, not before 30, for previous high-risk lesion
options.t: 1. In females with a previous diagnosis of a high-risk lesion꙳, we recommend annual mammography/DBT screening beginning at diagnosis, but not earlier than 30 years of age. (↑↑)

options.v: Annual MRI as adjunct for extremely dense breast tissue
options.t: ↪ 1.1 In females with extremely dense breast tissue (i.e., ACR category D), we suggest annual MRI as an adjunct. (↑)

options.v: Screening ultrasound as substitute if MRI is not tolerated, contraindicated, or unavailable
options.t: ↪ 1.2 In females where MRI is not tolerated, contraindicated, or unavailable, we suggest screening US as a substitute. (↑)

options.v: No imaging for implant evaluation in asymptomatic people
options.t: 1. In asymptomatic people, with breast implants of any type, we recommend against imaging for implant evaluation. (↓↓)

options.v: No imaging for clinically definitive saline implant rupture
options.t: 2. In people with saline breast implants and clinically definitive rupture, we recommend against imaging. (↓↓)

options.v: Ultrasound as initial imaging for suspected implant complications in under 30s
options.t: 3. In people under 30 years of age with suspected breast implant complications, we recommend US as the initial imaging technique. (↑↑)

options.v: Mammography/DBT and ultrasound as initial imaging for suspected implant complications in 30+
options.t: 4. In people 30 years and older with suspected breast implant complications, we recommend mammography/DBT and US as the initial imaging techniques. (↑↑)

options.v: MRI for optimal assessment if mammography/ultrasound findings are equivocal for suspected silicone implant rupture or lymphoma
options.t: 5. In people with suspected rupture of silicone breast implant or implant associated lymphoma and equivocal mammography/US findings, we recommend MRI for optimal assessment. (↑↑)

options.v: Cyclic or non-cyclic diffuse breast pain
No imaging beyond usual screening recommendations for cyclical, intermittent, or non-cyclic diffuse breast pain
options.t: 1. In patients with cyclical breast pain, intermittent breast pain, or non-cyclic diffuse breast pain, we recommend against imaging, beyond usual screening recommendations. (↓↓)

options.v: Targeted ultrasound as initial imaging for focal, non-cyclical persistent breast pain in under 30s
options.t: 1. In patients under 30 years of age with focal, non-cyclical persistent breast pain, we suggest targeted US as the initial imaging technique. (↑)

options.v: Bilateral mammography/DBT and targeted ultrasound as initial imaging for focal, non-cyclical persistent breast pain in 30+
options.t: 2. In patients 30 years of age and older, with focal, non-cyclical persistent breast pain, we recommend bilateral mammography/DBT and targeted US as the initial imaging techniques. (↑↑)

options.v: Mastitis/infection and abscess assessment: initial imaging
options.t: 1. In patients with clinical signs and symptoms of mastitis and suspected breast abscess, we recommend targeted US as the initial imaging technique. (↑↑)
2. In patients with no clinical improvement in suspected mastitis following antibiotics, we suggest diagnostic mammography/DBT and US as the initial imaging techniques. (EPc)

options.v: Patients with a history of breast cancer
Asymptomatic patients with history of breast cancer: surveillance
options.t: 1. In asymptomatic patients, with a personal history of breast cancer, we recommend annual surveillance mammography/DBT. (↑↑)

options.v: History of breast cancer with extremely dense breasts: surveillance
options.t: ↪ 1.1 In patients with history of breast cancer and extremely dense breast tissue (i.e., ACR category D), we suggest supplemental annual surveillance with US or MRI. (↑)

options.v: History of breast cancer: contralateral surveillance
options.t: 2. In patients with a history of breast cancer, we recommend contralateral annual surveillance mammography/DBT. (↑↑)

options.v: History of breast cancer and extremely dense breasts (ACR category D): supplemental surveillance
options.t: ↪ 2.1 In patients with history of breast cancer and extremely dense breast tissue (i.e., ACR category D), we suggest supplemental annual surveillance with US or MRI. (↑)

options.v: History of breast cancer without breast reconstruction: surveillance
options.t: 3. In patients with therapeutic mastectomy (bilateral or unilateral) without breast reconstruction, we suggest no imaging for breast cancer surveillance on the side(s) of mastectomy. (↓)

options.v: History of breast cancer without breast reconstruction with palpable concern: initial imaging
options.t: 4. In patients with therapeutic mastectomy without reconstruction presenting with a palpable area of concern, we recommend targeted US as the initial imaging technique. (↑↑)

options.v: History of breast cancer, mastectomy and reconstruction: surveillance
options.t: 5. In patients with therapeutic mastectomy and reconstruction (bilateral or unilateral), we suggest no imaging for breast cancer surveillance on the reconstructed side(s). (↓)

options.v: History of breast cancer with mastectomy and reconstruction with palpable concern: initial imaging
options.t: 6. In patients with therapeutic mastectomy and reconstruction presenting with a palpable area of concern, we recommend mammography/DBT and targeted US as the initial imaging techniques. (↑↑)

options.v: Patients following risk-reduction mastectomy (with or without autologous or implant-based reconstruction)
Reconstructed side(s) after risk-reduction mastectomy for breast cancer: screening
options.t: 1. In patients with risk-reduction mastectomy and reconstruction (bilateral or unilateral), we suggest no imaging for breast cancer screening on the reconstructed side(s). (↓)

options.v: Palpable concern after risk-reduction mastectomy with reconstruction: initial imaging
options.t: 2. In patients with risk-reduction mastectomy and reconstruction presenting with a palpable area of concern, we recommend mammography/DBT and targeted US as the initial imaging techniques. (↑↑)

options.v: After risk-reduction mastectomy without reconstruction: screening
options.t: 3. In patients with risk-reduction mastectomy without reconstruction, we suggest no imaging for breast cancer screening. (↓)

options.v: Palpable concern after risk-reduction mastectomy without reconstruction: initial imaging
options.t: 4. In patients with risk-reduction mastectomy without reconstruction presenting with a palpable area of concern, we recommend targeted US as the initial imaging technique. (↑↑)
